GameDBLocalizedString.Text: Genital discharge
Unusual discharge from the vagina, penis or bottom.
Pubic lice present
Crab (pubic) lice present in pubic hair.
Neisseria Gonorrhoeae detected
Tests have shown Neisseria Gonorrhoeae bacteria.
Chlamydia detected
Tests have shown Chlamydia bacteria.
Genital sores
Sores, warts or ulcers that typically appear on the penis, scrotum, vagina, vulva or around the anus.
Syphilis detected
Tests have shown Syphilis bacteria.
HIV detected
Tests have shown Human Immunodeficiency Virus.
HSV antibodies detected
Tests have shown the presence of antibodies to the Herpes Simplex Virus.
Scabies detected
Mites, eggs or burrow lines have indicated the presence of Scabies.
HPV detected
Genital screening has shown the presence of HPV.
MC detected
Physical examination has shown the presence of MC.
TV detected
Genital swab analysis has shown the presence of the Trichomoniasis virus.
BV detected
Genital swab analysis has shown the presence of bacterial vaginosis.
Cervicitis detected
Genital swab analysis has shown the presence of cervicitis.
Abnormal vaginal bleeding
Vaginal bleeding that occurs outside of the menstrual cycle.
Pain during sex
The patient experiences pain during sexual intercourse.
Mgen detected
Tests have shown the presence of mycoplasma genitalium.
Mgen detected
Tests have shown the presence of mycoplasma genitalium.
Testicular pain
The patient experiences testicular pain.
At risk
The patient is at high risk of HIV. Reasons can include sexuality, drug use or serodiscordant relationships.
Urethritis
Tests have shown the patient has urethritis.
Erectile dysfunction
The patient struggles to achieve or maintain an erection.
High semen volume
The patient reports an abnormally large ejaculate (or semen) volume.
Hyperspermia
Tests have shown the patient has hyperspermia.
Low semen volume
The patient reports an unusually low ejaculate (or semen) volume.
Hypospermia
Tests have shown the patient has hypospermia.
Epididymitis
Tests have shown the patient has epididymitis.
Phimosis
Phimosis is a condition where the foreskin is too tight to be pulled back over the head of the penis (glans).
Balanitis
A groin examination has shown the patient has balanitis.
Prostatitis
Tests have shown the patient has prostatitis.
Nail pitting
Nail pitting is the presence of pinpoint depressions on the nail surface, commonly seen in nail conditions associated with psoriasis or alopecia areata.
Photoexacerbation
Photoexacerbation is the worsening of skin lesions after sun exposure, suggesting a photosensitive/photoaggravated skin disease. Enhanced sun protection and avoidance of triggers help with control.
Symmetric malar macules
Symmetric malar macules are symmetrically distributed pigmented spots on the face, often associated with melasma; UV radiation and hormonal changes are common triggers.
Forehead involvement
Forehead involvement with symmetrically distributed pigmented spots, often associated with melasma; UV radiation and hormonal changes are common triggers.
Upper lip patch
Pigmented patch on the upper lip, often associated with melasma; UV radiation and hormonal changes are common triggers.
Koebner phenomenon
The Koebner phenomenon is the appearance of new skin lesions identical to the original disease at sites of trauma/scratching, seen in psoriasis, lichen planus, etc.
Collarette scale
A collarette scale is a scale with an inwardly folded collar-like shape, commonly seen in the 'herald patch' and secondary rashes of pityriasis rosea.
Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation

Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation is a pigmentary change following inflammation, resulting from inflammation-mediated melanin metabolism disorder; controlling the primary disease and sun protection are key.
Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation

Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation is a pigmentary change following inflammation, resulting from inflammation-mediated melanin metabolism disorder; controlling the primary disease and sun protection are key.
Increased sebum secretion
Increased sebum secretion is excessive sebum production, often associated with acne, androgen levels, and genetics.
Scalp scaling
Increased scaling on the scalp, seen in seborrheic dermatitis, tinea capitis, or psoriasis, requiring differentiation based on KOH test and clinical presentation.
Lichenification
Lichenification is a chronic change from scratching/rubbing, characterized by deepened skin lines and thickened skin, commonly seen in chronic eczema.
Excoriations/scratch marks
Excoriations/scratch marks are linear crusts/erosions formed by scratching due to itching, often indicating active pruritic dermatosis.
Satellite papules/pustules
Satellite papules/pustules are scattered small papules/pustules around a main lesion, commonly seen in cutaneous/mucosal candidiasis.
Annular raised border
An annular raised border is a sign of annular erythema with a raised periphery and relatively clear center, suggesting superficial fungal diseases like tinea corporis/cruris.
Central clearing
A pattern where the center of a skin lesion improves or clears up while the outer edge continues to expand, often seen in fungal infections like ringworm.
Flushing induced by hot drinks/alcohol
The patient reports episodes of facial redness and warmth that are triggered by consuming hot beverages, spicy foods, or alcoholic drinks, a common feature of rosacea.
Papulopustules
The presence of small, red, inflamed bumps (papules) and pus-filled lesions (pustules) on the skin, characteristic of conditions like acne or papulopustular rosacea.
Greasy scale
Yellowish, oily scales or flakes on the skin, typically found in areas rich in oil glands such as the scalp, face, and chest. A key sign of seborrheic dermatitis.
Onycholysis
The painless separation of the nail from the nail bed, starting at the tip and progressing towards the base. It can be associated with psoriasis, fungal infections, or trauma.
Positive NAAT for Chlamydia trachomatis L1–L3
Positive nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) for Chlamydia trachomatis L1–L3 supports the diagnosis of LGV.
Donovan bodies on smear/biopsy
Presence of Donovan bodies on smear/biopsy suggests granuloma inguinale (donovanosis).
Budding yeast/pseudohyphae on 10% KOH prep of vaginal discharge
Presence of budding yeast/pseudohyphae on KOH microscopy of vaginal discharge is consistent with Candida infection.
Open/closed comedones (blackheads/whiteheads)

Comedones are the hallmark lesions of acne, consisting of hair follicles clogged with sebum and dead skin cells. Open comedones (blackheads) have a dark surface, while closed comedones (whiteheads) are skin-colored bumps.
Persistent centrofacial flushing with visible telangiectasias
Persistent redness in the central face, accompanied by fine, visible, dilated blood vessels (telangiectasias). This is a characteristic feature of erythematotelangiectatic rosacea.
Flexural eczematous lesions with significant pruritus and lichenification

Itchy, inflamed skin patches located in the body's folds (e.g., behind the knees, inside the elbows). Chronic scratching leads to thickened, leathery skin (lichenification), a common presentation of atopic dermatitis.
Blanchable, migratory wheals

Raised, itchy, and swollen skin welts (wheals) that turn white when pressed. Individual lesions are transient, typically resolving within 24 hours and appearing in new locations, characteristic of urticaria (hives).
Pinpoint bleeding after scale removal
Well-demarcated erythematous scaly plaques with pinpoint bleeding after scale removal, consistent with psoriasis features.
Depigmented patches with milky-white fluorescence under Wood's lamp
Milky-white fluorescence under Wood's lamp suggests epidermal melanin loss (e.g., vitiligo).
Hyaline septate hyphae on 10-20% KOH prep of skin scrapings
Presence of hyaline septate hyphae on KOH wet mount suggests dermatophyte infection.
Positive KOH prep of groin skin scrapings
Presence of hyaline septate hyphae on KOH wet mount suggests dermatophyte infection.
Black dot alopecia (broken hairs) or positive KOH hair exam
Black dot appearance left by broken hairs, common in endothrix tinea capitis.
Short hyphae + yeast clusters on KOH prep
Presence of short hyphae and clusters of yeast ('spaghetti and meatballs') on KOH prep, typical of tinea versicolor.
Black dots/pinpoint bleeding after shaving
Pinpoint black dots/bleeding after shaving off the stratum corneum, caused by thrombosed capillaries within the wart.
Multiple small, flat papules in clusters on face/hands/legs
Multiple small, flat papules in clusters, consistent with flat warts.
Honey-colored crusts
Golden honey-colored crusts, typical of impetigo.
'Herald patch' followed by Christmas tree distribution
A larger oval scaly patch appears first, followed by a 'Christmas tree' distribution of secondary rashes a few days later.
'Exclamation mark hairs' at the edge of hair loss
Short broken hairs that are thinner at the proximal end and thicker at the distal end, resembling an 'exclamation mark', suggesting active alopecia areata.
Wickham's striae on lesion surface
Fine, reticular white lines on the lesion surface, a characteristic sign of lichen planus.
Granular IgA deposits in dermal papillae on direct immunofluorescence
Direct immunofluorescence showing granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae supports the diagnosis of dermatitis herpetiformis.
Epidermal pigmentation enhanced under Wood's lamp
Enhanced border and color of pigmented spots under Wood's lamp, suggesting primarily epidermal pigmentation.
Sinus tracts and scarring in axilla/groin
Subcutaneous sinus tracts and scarring formed after recurrent nodules and abscesses, a chronic change of hidradenitis suppurativa.
Greasy, scaly erythematous plaques in seborrheic areas
Greasy, scaly erythematous plaques in seborrheic areas like the face/chest/back, suggesting seborrheic dermatitis.
Scabies burrows visible in finger webs/wrist flexures
Fine, long, winding burrow-like lines visible in areas like finger webs and wrist flexures, often with intense itching, suggesting scabies.
